title: Online trolls slam Loose Women for claiming female retirement age should stay the same
text:
Loose Women panelists have been accused of hypocrisy after claiming women should get to retire earlier than men - to make up for not being paid equally during their working lives.

Following yesterday's High Court ruling that raising the state pension age for women to 66, in line with men, is not discriminatory, Kaye Adams, Nadia Sawalha, Kéllé Bryan and Carol McGiffin discussed whether it's fair that women should be made to work later into their lives.

Nadia, 54, argued that the issue of equal pay needed to be dealt with before the age of retirement was raised, as the pay gap means women make less money in their working life.

However the presenter was met by hoards of comments, mainly from men, claiming that she doesn't want 'equality' and simply wants to 'have her cake and eat it'.

On today's episode of Loose Women Kaye Adams (far left), Kéllé Bryan(left), Carol McGiffin (right)and Nadia Sawalha (far right) discussed whether it was right for the retirement age for women was raised from 60 to 66

Nadia, 54, argued that the issue of equal pay needed to be dealt with before the age of retirement was raised

The debate followed yesterday's High Court ruling that means up to 4 million women must keep working after ministers raised their state pension age from 60 to 66.

Two women – Julie Delve, 61, and Karen Glynn, 63 – brought the legal challenge, arguing that the changes were discriminatory on the grounds of age and sex, and that they were not given adequate notice.

But two High Court judges dismissed their claims on all grounds, and yesterday's ruling means up to 4 million women must keep working after ministers raised their state pension age from 60 to 66.

During the debate, Kaye, 56, said: 'I guess there will be men out they're saying "I'm tired too".'

However the presenter was met by hoards of comments, mainly from men, claiming that she doesn't want 'equality'

Nadia quickly responded: 'Wouldn't it be great if we had equal pay? That would be a good way to start. Let's have equal pay first.'

Kéllé, 44, pointed out that by their 60s women have an average of £51,000 in their pension pots - a third of what a man has, which is £156,000.

She was adamant that the retirement age shouldn't be raised, saying: 'I think it should remain the same I think it should be 60, I don't think it should be 65.'

One furious user claimed: 'Women want equality, yet they don’t want the same retirement age as men, because that’s how equality works.'

Singer and actress Kéllé also insisted that equality should be 'across the board' if the retirement age has been made equal to men's

Another commented: 'I suppose if I was a woman, I'd want my cake and eat it too, if I could. #thatsLife'.

A third raged: 'Of course the retirement age for men and women should be equal. Women have it much easier than men and they live longer.'.

Singer and actress Kéllé insisted that equality should be 'across the board' and went on to point out that some women's working lives are restricted due to the strain of having children.

The state pension: Questions and answers What are the changes to women’s state pension age? The plan to raise the women’s state pension age from 60 to 65 to bring it in line with men was first revealed in the 1995 Pensions Act. In 2007 it was decided that the pensionable age for men and women would rise to 66 by April 2026. This deadline was brought forward in 2011 so that the retirement age for both sexes will be 66 by October 2020. It will rise to 67 by 2028. What was the legal challenge? Most campaigners support pension age equality, but say it was introduced unlawfully. They have argued that women were not adequately informed about the changes or given enough time to adjust. The changes to the state pension age affect all women born after April 6, 1950. But those born after April 6, 1953 – who are now in their early 60s – are hit especially hard. Some have lost out on up to £50,000. The BackTo60 group argued that women born during the 1950s took time out of work to care for children, were paid less than men and could not save as much in occupational pensions, so the change had hit them harder. It is estimated that 3.8 million women are in this position. What was the High Court judgment? Lord Justice Irwin and Mrs Justice Whipple dismissed the women’s case on all grounds. The judges said the Government was under no obligation to notify the women. They said there was no discrimination based on age and even if there had been it could be justified by the objective of achieving a fair and affordable pension system. They said the new laws in fact corrected historic discrimination against men by levelling the state pension age. What happens next? Campaigners have vowed to fight on and say they will ask Parliament to intervene. If they pursue their legal challenge, the case will go to the Court of Appeal, and possibly the Supreme Court.

She said: 'If we're gonna talk about equality, let's make it across the board so we make the same amount of money.

'We've got to think about the things like we have children. I'm not saying we're the weaker sex, but it's different. We have a different like experience to men.

'We have children, we're the primary child care givers, and so therefore there are different stresses and pressures - and also the amount of time that we can psychically work for.

However trolls continued to rage about the debate - with one branding her a 'has been' and saying she wants equality that 'suits her'

'Carrying a child for nine months for a start, then I've got to give birth to that child. I've got to breastfeed that child, there's time I've taken off work.'

However, viewers continued to rage about the debate - with one saying she wants equality that 'suits her'.

Another said: 'Some Women want equality, but only on things that suit them.'

A third added: 'You wanted equality! Stop moaning because you have to work to a later age! Us men just have to get on with it!'
description: Loose Women panelists have been accused of hypocrisy after claiming women should get to retire earlier than men - to make up for not being paid equally during their working lives.
